Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: A Microscope Stage-Mounted Miniaturized Tissue Sectioning Device Enabling Automated, Extended 3-D Volume Imaging of Fluorescent Protein Labeled Biological Samples
Award.AbstractNarration:
Genetically encoded fluorescent protein tags are excellent tools for directly visualizing specific cell populations, ideally suited for studying multi-cellular events such as tissue differentiation, organ growth and the establishment of neural connectivity dispersed over large regions. Using fluorescent protein technologies to study large samples in their entirety at high resolution will provide unprecedented insight into the interactions and interdependencies that occur throughout the sample. Unfortunately, the field of view of current high-resolution imaging tools is severely restricted, making it difficult to study large samples. Extended volume imaging techniques allow multiple, overlapping regions to be imaged in order to reconstruct a high-resolution, composite, three dimensional volume much larger than a single microscopic field of view. However, the best currently available techniques are not compatible with fluorescent protein signal, because they employ an organic solvent-based embedding procedure that can denature fluorescent proteins that ruins their fluorescence and prevents direct visualization.

To fill this unmet need, an automated, integrated aqueous tissue sectioning microscope stage will be developed and deployed. Compatibility with fluorescent proteins is maintained by eliminating all organic-solvent processing steps. Furthermore, by miniaturizing the device, it will be made compatible with the standard upright laser scanning microscopes that biologists, neuroscientists and other practitioners are currently using.

The features, design and implementation of the aqueous tissue sectioning microscope stage for three dimensional, extended volume imaging will be publicly disseminated in both publications and on web pages of the Caltech Biological Imaging Center. In addition, optimized protocols for mounting, sectioning and imaging samples from a variety of model organisms will be freely distributed to facilitate widespread adoption of the new device. The eventual widespread availability of this modular microscope accessory will allow researchers from all over the world to modify an existing laser scanning microscope to perform three dimensional extended volume imaging of fluorescent protein labeled biological samples. Undergraduate students will be involved in the multidisciplinary instrument development project through the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship program, and representation of underrepresented students in science and engineering will be increased through the Minority Undergraduate Research Fellowship program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imaging large tissue samples at high resolution is valuable for understanding important biological processes. Identifying and characterizing interdependencies and interconnectivities within a sample is greatly facilitated by being able to image the sample in its entirety. Imaging modalities such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computed tomography (CT) are well suited for large samples in their entirety, however, the resolution of these techniques is low and individual cells cannot be resolved. Confocal laser-scanning microscopy (CLSM) is a routine optical imaging technique that offers cellular and sub-cellular resolution. However, the field of view of conventional confocal microscopy is limited to a few hundred microns. To overcome this limitation, Extended Volume Imaging techniques have been developed to allow multiple, adjacent regions to be imaged successively in order to reconstruct a 3-D volume much larger than a single microscopic field of view.

The goal of this NSF funded project was to develop a cost effective, portable microscope accessory that enables researchers to perform Extended Volume Imaging with an already existing laser scanning confocal microscope. The added functionality afforded by this microscope accessory will allow more researchers to include Extended Volume Imaging in their experiments without having to purchase a dedicated microscope system. Further benefits of our device is that samples are prepared and imaged in an aqueous environment that maintains the tissue’s physiological geometries and preserves the fluorescence of genetically encoded fluorescent protein tags such as green fluorescent protein (GFP).

Our microscope accessory combines the optical sectioning capability of a CLSM with a vibratome type oscillating tissue-sectioning device. To perform an Extended Volume Imaging experiment the sample is first embedded in a block of an aqueous matrix (e.g. agarose or acrylamide) and mounted into the buffer filled basin on the microscope stage. A motorized stage assemblage coordinates and drives automated mosaic (tiled) imaging. The upper layer of the tissue sample is imaged as laterally adjacent tiled volumes. Once the entire upper layer is imaged, a portion of the imaged Z thickness is removed from the sample block using the oscillating tissue-sectioning device. Then, the next underlying volume is imaged. This process is repeated until the entire desired Z dimension of the entire sample is covered. The resultant datasets are stitched together into a large composite volume that represents the entire region that was imaged. To assist with the 3-D reconstruction process, we also developed software routines for stitching the sub-volumes together. The fully stitched composite volume can then be reconstructed in 3-D using commonly used 3-D volumetric visualization software packages such as FIJI/ImageJ and Imaris (Bitplane).

In order to enhance widespread adoption of our Extended Volume Imaging technique, we worked with researchers to develop sample preparation protocols and refined imaging routines for a variety of samples including embryonic transgenic mice and quail, mouse lungs, and tumors. We have also actively sought out industrial partnerships in order to have our device commercially manufactured for widespread availability.

Its portability and ease of set-up allows the device to be deployed when needed and then taken down when the microscope is needed for conventional imaging experiments.
